{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3329319,"name":"Rishi Desai","username":"rdesai14","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/3ab097/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-10T21:34:17.783Z","cooked":"

Hey Guys, I’m trying to figure out how to add a limelight pose to the CTRE Swerve X odometry. Would I simply just add it to the telemetry.java file? Also, once that happens, how would I go about using the limelight to then rotate to auto-align with the speaker/amp using the swerve code by CTRE?

Our code is listed below

GitHub

GitHub - 7451AvengerRobotics/FRC2024

Contribute to 7451AvengerRobotics/FRC2024 development by creating an account on GitHub.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-03-10T21:34:17.783Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1435,"reads":413,"readers_count":412,"score":7272.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":458162,"topic_slug":"pose-with-limelight-drive-to-pose","display_username":"Rishi Desai","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/7451AvengerRobotics/FRC2024","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - 7451AvengerRobotics/FRC2024","clicks":116}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57090,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Head Programming for 7451"},"post_url":"/t/pose-with-limelight-drive-to-pose/458162/1","custom_user_title":"Head Programming for 7451","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3329513,"name":"","username":"jgarder","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/a183cd/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-11T01:55:45.556Z","cooked":"

get the pose of your chassis, then use pids to make it the pose you want.

CommandSwerveDrivetrain.getState().Pose or whatever… then use some pids to apply a request to your private final SwerveRequest.FieldCentric drive command and have the pids outputs push you in the xy and rotation you want

this only works if you have the limelight setup to update your odometry automatically. if you want to use the limelights field coordinates they are under limelight networktable with the name WpiBlue. blue team is what everyone uses for field coords. red is unused unless you build a specific use case.

also the ctre example swerve includes some pieces that add vision measurments I.e. limelight updates odometry, so look that up!

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2024-03-11T02:01:32.801Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":93,"reads":387,"readers_count":386,"score":542.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":458162,"topic_slug":"pose-with-limelight-drive-to-pose","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57486,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pose-with-limelight-drive-to-pose/458162/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3329525,"name":"mjbergman92","username":"mjbergman92","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjbergman92/{size}/219086_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-11T02:09:57.806Z","cooked":"

If it helps, here is our code HOC-Team-3534/MusicalToaster (github.com)

We use pathplanner and the CTRE Swerve Library.

We are not currently path generating on the fly, but we could easily do it if needed.
If you are trying to drive in autonomous, and you want to feed your pose estimation from limelight to the CTRE SwerveDrivetrain class instance, then you need to call "addVisionMeasurement(Pose2d, timestamp). The timestamp should be the NT4 timestamp, which since NT4 is hosted on the roboRIO, is relative to the FPGATimer on the roboRIO. That way, when you give it the pose estimation, the SwervePoseEstimator can account for the latency.

If you take a look at ours, we use photon vision, so a little different, but the concept is the same. Get the Pose3d to a Pose2d and pull the timestamp from network tables (I assume LL has updated since I used it last to using NT4 timestamps) and make your implementation of SwerveDrivetrain be a Singleton (using createInstance and getInstance like we did for all our subsystems, so we dont have to pass instances around in our code), or you can pass a lambda expression to your LimeLight class that grabs the data from the LL and call this lambda expression which would be a BiConsumer (i think) and that way you can fill that lambda expression with the addVisionMeasurement method of your SwerveDrivetrain extended class.

EDIT:

Here is some helpful areas that might be of use to you.

This is what makes our classes for our subsystems only be able to produce one instance, that way we don’t have to pass around the instances in our code. MusicalToaster/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/swervedrive/CommandSwerveDrivetrain.java at 24a7d229c47af4a1199848469198303523e80e36 · HOC-Team-3534/MusicalToaster · GitHub

Here is the actual call that takes what we pull from network tables for photonvision (which should be similar to limelight, just a different library with similar goals) MusicalToaster/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/camera/PhotonVisionCamera.java at 24a7d229c47af4a1199848469198303523e80e36 · HOC-Team-3534/MusicalToaster · GitHub

EDIT 2:

As for auto aligning, I suggest making a ProfilePIDCommand. It’s quite easy. I wish I had an example to show you at the moment. Create a class that extends ProfilePIDCommand class… I really wish I had an example. Someone wanna give an example of a ProfilePIDCommand for turning if I can’t find one?

What a ProfilePIDCommand is going to do is control the turning using a ProfilePIDController. The different between a profile PID and a PID is simple.

A standard PID goes straight for your end goal/target, which is the orientation you want to turn to in your case; however, this leads to overshoot since the constants of PID have to be tuned for say an error of 90 degrees and 1 degree with the same tunings. There are ways around it, but a typical PID corrects directly to the end goal.

A Profiled PID factors in a few more variables, those being your max cruise velocity and acceleration. This way, instead of shooting straight for the goal, it knows that your mechanism has to speed up, cruise, and then slow down to smoothly reach your end goal orientation without overshoot. The PID is now used instead of correcting on the end goal, it is used to correct to the point on the velocity curve describe previously with your chosen accel (which is also decel) and cruise velocity, so that it looks like a trapezoid, hence the term Trapezoidal Profile.

Feel free to PM if you have questions related to the output of the ProfiledPIDCommand or post back here. I don’t have much more time to explain the output right now. Hopefully someone else could fill you in on the output side of the command.

HOC-Team-3534/MusicalToaster","clicks":147},{"url":"https://github.com/HOC-Team-3534/MusicalToaster/blob/24a7d229c47af4a1199848469198303523e80e36/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/swervedrive/CommandSwerveDrivetrain.java#L50C1-L93C6","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"MusicalToaster/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/swervedrive/CommandSwerveDrivetrain.java at 24a7d229c47af4a1199848469198303523e80e36 · HOC-Team-3534/MusicalToaster · GitHub","clicks":38},{"url":"https://github.com/HOC-Team-3534/MusicalToaster/blob/24a7d229c47af4a1199848469198303523e80e36/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/camera/PhotonVisionCamera.java#L76C24-L77C118","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"MusicalToaster/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/camera/PhotonVisionCamera.java at 24a7d229c47af4a1199848469198303523e80e36 · HOC-Team-3534/MusicalToaster · GitHub","clicks":34}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29382,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pose-with-limelight-drive-to-pose/458162/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3329542,"name":"Trevor G.","username":"Pi_Fighter","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/db5fbb/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-11T02:27:08.629Z","cooked":"

For the pose, we changed the drivetrain declaration in RobotContainer from private to public, so then we can add the limelight pose in RobotPeriodic. From there, we just implemented the basic example from the Limelight website. It ended up looking like this, in RobotPeriodic:

    if (enableLimelight) {
      //Periodically retrieve the results from the limelight and extract the pose.
      LimelightHelpers.PoseEstimate limelightMeasurement = LimelightHelpers.getBotPoseEstimate_wpiBlue(Constants.kLimelightName);
      if (limelightMeasurement.tagCount >= 2) {
        m_robotContainer.drivetrain.setVisionMeasurementStdDevs(VecBuilder.fill(0.7, 0.7, 9999999));
        m_robotContainer.drivetrain.addVisionMeasurement(limelightMeasurement.pose, limelightMeasurement.timestampSeconds);
      }

We set enableLimelight to false, because we really didn’t need odometry after autonomous.

We implemented a command to use the limelight data to turn to position. Basically, we check the Limelight, and if we see the AprilTags directly under the speaker, we add the TX value to our current angle, and set that as a PID setpoint, with our pigeon heading as the reference. That PID output is used as the rotational rate for the swerve control. Then, we wait until our TX is close to 0, then use the TY to calculate our distance, update our shooter arm angle, and then shoot the note.

Here is our code. The command is in src/main/java/frc/robot/commands/Driver/ShooterModeShootWithLimelight.java

GitHub

GitHub - frc1718/2024-BuildSeason-1718: Code for Team 1718's 2024 Robot, Nessie.

Code for Team 1718's 2024 Robot, Nessie. Contribute to frc1718/2024-BuildSeason-1718 development by creating an account on GitHub.

Additionally, check the CTRE API, specifically SwerveRequest.FieldCentricFacingAngle (CTRE Phoenix 6 Java 24.2.0). I’ve only used it in simulation, but you can constantly update the target angle in order to track a point on the field.

Pi_Fighter:

we changed the drivetrain declaration in RobotContainer from private to public, so then we can add the limelight pose in RobotPeriodic

I highly recommend using the Singleton method I showed. It allows us to use Optional, that way we can disable entire subsystems and still have the rest of the robot completely functional.

It looks like you’re using the 24.1.0 version of the Phoenix v6 library, based on your vendordeps. There should be an update to the 24.2.0 version available.

If you’re looking at our CommandSwerveDrivetrain.java, a couple of those methods (the periodic() override, and the SysIdRoutine methods) were copied from CTRE’s SwerveWithPathPlanner example. I believe those are auto-generated now, if you create a new project with the Tuner X Swerve Generator.

Hey Guys thanks for the help. We wrote the code for the auto alignment and pose estimation. Could you guys take a look and see if it would theoretically work? We just had our competition and so after mechanical fixes some issues we will test but any changes that should be made before then?
